greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table of partitions of n into distinct parts, in Mathematica ordering.
comment: Reverse lexicographic order where the partitions are reprepresented as (weakly) decreasing lists of parts. [_Joerg Arndt_, Jan 25 2013]
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..32, flattened
example: The partitions of 5 into distinct parts are [5], [4,1] and [3,2], so row 5 is 5,4,1,3,2.
mathematica: d[n_] := Select[IntegerPartitions[n], Max[Length /@ Split@ #] == 1 &]; Flatten[Table[d[n], {n, 15}]] (* _Clark Kimberling_, Mar 11 2012 *)
program: def StrictPartitions(n): return [partition for partition in Partitions(n) if Set(partition.to_exp()).issubset(Set([0,1]))]
def A118457row(n): return [p for parts in StrictPartitions(n) for p in parts]
for n in (1..9): print(A118457row(n)) # _Peter Luschny_, Apr 11 2020
xref: Cf. A026793, A118459 (partition lengths), A015723 (total row lengths), A080577, A000009, A246688.
results.author: _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Apr 28 2006
